qas.question: Al-Farabi concluded a perfect vacuum was incoherent using what?
Ibn al-Haytham used geometry to demonstrate  what?

answers.text: place (al-makan) is the imagined three-dimensional void between the inner surfaces of a containing body

qas.question: who stated that there was no evidence to rule out a vacuum?
what did Al-Farabi say expanded to fill available space
What type of pump appeared in the 15th century?

plausible_answers.text: is the imagined three-dimensional void between the inner surfaces of a containing body

qas.question: What was Aristotle able to demonstrate about place?
In what century did Aristotle develop the suction pump?
What did Aristotle investigate to test the existence of a vacuum?

plausible_answers.text: concept of perfect vacuum was incoherent

qas.question: What did Aristotle suggest about the concept of a perfect vacuum after his experiment?
What did Aristotle state there was no evidence to rule out?

context: In the medieval Middle Eastern world, the physicist and Islamic scholar, Al-Farabi (Alpharabius, 872–950), conducted a small experiment concerning the existence of vacuum, in which he investigated <a0_0><b7_0>handheld plungers in water<b7_0/>.<a0_0/>[unreliable source?] He concluded that <a3_0>air's volume<a3_0/> can expand to fill available space, and he suggested that the <b8_0>concept of perfect vacuum was incoherent<b8_0/>. However, according to Nader El-Bizri, the physicist Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen, 965–1039) and the Mu'tazili theologians disagreed with Aristotle and Al-Farabi, and they supported the existence of a void. Using geometry, Ibn al-Haytham mathematically demonstrated that <a1_0>place (al-makan) <b5_0>is the imagined three-dimensional void between the inner surfaces of a containing body<b5_0/><a1_0/>. According to Ahmad Dallal, <a2_0>Abū Rayhān al-Bīrūnī<a2_0/> also states that "there is no observable evidence that rules out <b9_0>the possibility of vacuum<b9_0/>". The <a4_0>suction pump<a4_0/> later appeared in Europe from the <b6_0>15th century<b6_0/>.
